channel.title: Joy of Coding
channel.description: Recent content on Joy of Coding

item.title: AIsland
item.description: By Dion van Dam During the conference, the huge video wall will be running an AI programming challenge. Code your own bot on your laptop and watch it compete with other people’s bots on the big screen. AIsland is a turn-based strategy game for 2-8 bot players, entered for each round by their humans. The winner of each round is the bot that successfully takes over the generated island landscape by removing the other players.

item.title: Carin Meier
item.description: The Joy of Stochastic Gradient Descent We’ll take a look at the joys of Deep Learning from its simple, elegant fundamentals to its feats of impressive power. Along the way, we’ll discuss how Deep Learning is changing how we approach programming, communicate with each other, and even what it means to be human. On Twitter she is known as @gigasquid

item.title: How to hire and work with people who aren’t like you
item.description: How to hire and work with people who aren’t like you Diversity and Inclusion initiatives have cost many technology companies hundreds of millions but there has been little change in who works in tech. This talk will examine conventional wisdom in changing the workforce makeup in tech, how we got to our current state and what practical actions companies can take so that diversity is built into their cultural operation system.

item.title: Jessica Kerr
item.description: Shaving the Golden Yak Programming is a series of frustrations. Everything we do, we could do better or faster if we only had our tools set up just so. If our error messages were a little better, our code a little cleaner, our tests a lot wider. How do you balance the work you’re supposed to be doing with the work that makes your work, work? Dive into the yak stack with me.

item.title: Lightning talks
item.description: Can everyone be a programmer? Shiva Schroders Everyone has something of value Adrian Cole - @adrianfcole Event Sourcing from 1918 and before Herman Peeren - @HermanPeeren What comes after Rock, Paper, Scissors, (Lizard, Spock) Daan van Berkel - @daan_van_berkel The joy of a microservices monorepo Alex Nederlof - @alexnederlof The cool things we learn in our Coderclass Israh Emara - @metiscoderclass The Joy of Joggling Roy van Rijn - @royvanrijn

item.title: Living the Good Life
item.description: Living the Good Life Most people imagine the ancient Greek philosophers to be white-haired old men with nothing better to do, running around trying to solve impossible questions like, ‘How do we know the world exists if we have no senses?’ or ‘If a tree falls in a forest, with no one around to hear it, does it still make noise?’. Most of the time, we consider these questions nonsensical, inane, and not really worth the time to debate except when really, really drunk.

item.title: Mob Programming
item.description: Mob Programming If you think pair programming (2 people on 1 computer) is crazy, hold onto your hats; it’s time for Mob Programming. Mob Programming: All the brilliant people working on the same thing, at the same time, in the same place, and on the same computer. We are going to take a look at a new way of working, what it looks like, and why it can work.

item.title: Neal Ford
item.description: Stories Every Developer Should Know “Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it.” – George Santayana “The past is never dead. It’s not even past.” – William Faulkner Most architects and developers pursue the Latest and Greatest with great fervor, yet the history of engineering, including software projects, contains rich lessons that we risk repeating ad nauseam. This keynote recounts a variety of stories of projects that failed architecturally…and why.

item.title: RoboCup Junior
item.description: RoboCup Junior is a robot competition for kids up to 19 years of age, with categories for soccer, rescue and dance. Teams that compete in the dance division create both a robot and a dance composition for the robot to perform. Each entry consists of a two-minute dance performance choreographed to music, with particular attention for construction and programming. Team members can join in to dance alongside the robot.

item.title: Speed Meeting
item.description: By Linda van der Pal Whether you’ve never attended a developer conference before, or if you’ve been around the circuit for years, occasionally they can be a lonely experience. Joy of Coding tries to remove that feeling with a session of Speed Meeting. In this session you will introduce yourself to several other conference attendees in short introductions of a few minutes each. In this introduction you are invited to talk with one other participant about who you both are, and why you are here.

item.title: About
item.description: We are organising for fun, not for profit. The people behind Joy of Coding are an informal group, backed by a legal entity (the Devnology Foundation). We are organising this for fun, not for profit. Felienne Hermans I am assistant professor and speaker. I strive to make programming better and easier for non-programmers. I love functional programming and board games. @felienne Arne Timmerman Software engineer and community facilitator.

item.title: Joy of Coding
item.description: Joy of coding is all about the love for programming. Learn about new and emerging technologies from companies and academia. Get inspired by renowned international speakers. Pair with fellow passionate developers in one of the workshops. Friday 30 June 2017 @ De Rotterdamse Schouwburg, Rotterdam

item.title: Code of Conduct
item.description: Celebrating the art, craft, science and joy of software development ―  Code of Conduct All attendees, speakers, hosts, sponsors and volunteers (all these further referred to as participants) at our events are subject to the following code of conduct. We will enforce this code throughout all our events and are expecting cooperation from all participants to help ensuring a safe environment for everybody. No harrassment We are dedicated to providing harassment-free events for everyone, regardless of gender, age, sexual orientation, disability, physical appearance, body size, race, or religion (or lack thereof).

item.title: Schedule 2017
item.description: Hi there, have a look at our 2017 schedule! Have a look at al the inspiring speakers that will come to Rotterdam on 30 June. Most slots are links to more detailed information. 08:30 - 09:20 08:30 - 09:20 Walk in @ Main hall 08:30 - 09:20 Registration @ Foyer 09:20 - 09:30 09:20 - 09:30 Opening and introduction to the AIsland Game Contest @ Main hall 09:30 - 10:10 Keynote09:30 - 10:10 Living the good life Ted Neward@ Main hall 10:10 - 10:50 10:10 - 10:50 Break @ Foyer Game10:10 - 10:50 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 10:50 - 11:30 Talk10:50 - 11:30 Shaving the golden yak Jessica Kerr@ Main hall Game10:50 - 11:30 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 11:30 - 12:10 Community11:30 - 12:10 Lightning talks @ Main hall Networking11:30 - 12:10 Speed meeting @ Foyer 12:10 - 13:10 12:10 - 13:10 Lunch @ Foyer Game12:10 - 13:10 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 13:10 - 13:50 Keynote13:10 - 13:50 Stories every developer should know Neal Ford@ Main hall 13:50 - 14:30 Talk13:50 - 14:30 Mob programming Llewellyn Falco@ Main hall Game13:50 - 14:30 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 14:30 - 15:10 14:30 - 15:10 Break @ Foyer Game14:30 - 15:10 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 15:10 - 15:50 Talk15:10 - 15:50 How to hire and work with people who aren’t like you Koshin Mariano@ Main hall Game15:10 - 15:50 AIsland Game Contest @ Foyer 15:50 - 16:30 Keynote15:50 - 16:30 The joy of stochastic gradient descent Carin Meier@ Main hall 16:30 - 16:50 16:30 - 16:50 RoboCup Junior demo @ Main hall 16:50 - 20:00 16:50 - 20:00 Drinks/dinner @ Foyer Game17:30 AIsland finals @ Foyer Tickets 2017

item.title: Venue
item.description: Celebrating the art, craft, science and joy of software development ―  Our 2017 venue: De Rotterdamse Schouwburg Joy of Coding 2017 will take place at the Rotterdamse Schouwburg, a theatre in the centre of Rotterdam. While this venue usually hosts dance, theatre and music theatre productions, it offers ideal conference facilities. The location is on the central Rotterdam square of the same name, Schouwbergplein. Getting there Address: Rotterdamse Schouwburg, Schouwburgplein 25, 3012 CL Rotterdam
